2.7. Modules

A file is actually a closure. Let's take the simple mysimplefile.zs file below as an example.

mysimplefile.zs
const int a = 1, b = 2, c = 3;
return [a, b, c];

2.7.1. compile_file

A file can be compiled by using compile_file(...), a closure will be returned on success. It can then be executed like a normal function call.

Output  [Figure 1]
[1,2,3]
This is basically the same thing as doing this:

There is no caching or anything else involve when calling compile_file(...), the file will be recompiled at every call.

Output  [Figure 3]
0x00006000026ec1e0 [1,2,3]
0x0000600000f480a0 [1,2,3]

2.7.2. load_file

A file can also be compiled and executed in one command.

Output  [Figure 4]
[1,2,3]

2.7.3. this

The value of this in ZScript depends on how a function is invoked. When a regular function is invoked as a method of an object obj.method(), this points to that object. When invoked as a standalone function, this typically refers to the root object.

myobjectfile.zs
this.a = 10;

Output  [Figure 5]
before - this.a: 0
after  - this.a: 10

before - obj1.a: 1
after  - obj1.a: 10

before - obj2.a: 2
after  - obj2.a: 10
All other components for managing modules are built upon this foundation.

2.7.4. import

Given these two files (dummy1.zs and dummy2.zs):

dummy1.zs
// This is a local table variable.
var dummy1 = {};

// This is a local const variable.
const my_local_var = 34;

// This is a local closure.
function my_local_do_something(a, b) {
  return (a + b) * my_local_var;
}

// This adds the `do_something` closure to the `dummy1` table.
function dummy1.do_something(a, b) {
  return 54 + my_local_do_something(a, b);
}

// Returns the dummy1 table.
return dummy1;

dummy2.zs
zs.print("dummy2")
